148381909.review:
[h1] 9/10 [/h1]

NekoPara vol.0 adalah novel visual kinetik yang pendek (Anda akan melihat bagian akhirnya dalam waktu sekitar satu setengah jam).
Novel ini tidak melibatkan percintaan atau kencan, dan tidak memberi Anda satu pun pilihan untuk dipilih. Anda hanya membaca ceritanya, mengikuti para catgirl Minaduki dan kehidupan gila mereka selama satu hari penuh.

Sebagian besar adegan kecilnya terkadang sangat lucu, terkadang tidak terlalu lucu, tetapi selalu tidak masuk akal. Anda akan menyukai karakter-karakternya, semua dengan keunikannya masing-masing, dan tentunya dengan preferensi terhadap salah satu dari mereka.

Meskipun sebagian besar game ini sama sekali tidak memiliki layanan penggemar, kami masih mendapatkan momen mesum di beberapa titik. Tidak ada yang terlalu nakal, jadi 90% dari game ini BISA dimainkan di tempat umum tanpa rasa takut.

Visualnya sangat indah. Meskipun sebagian besar CG-nya bergaya chibi dalam prekuel ini, masih ada beberapa yang luar biasa (termasuk NSFW), dan seni karakternya indah dan dianimasikan dengan baik.

Jadi, jika kalian ingin mencoba beberapa potongan kehidupan yang lucu dan menggemaskan, NekoPara vol.0 pasti bisa menghibur kalian di sore hari.

147296909.review: Nekopara 0 is an Adult Visual Novel and is a Fandisk (Mini Prequel) to Nekopara 1 and happens pretty soon before the first game. Playing the first one is needed so you know who the characters are in this game, but if you want to play this first, it's not that big of a deal. In the game, you follow Shigure Minaduki and the 6 catgirls from the Minaduki Family; Chocola, Vanilla, Maple, Cinnamon, Azuki and Coconut. This game is based on a day in the life of Shigure and the Six Catgirls and how they live. You get to see how all 6 catgirls' personalities are and how they interact with each other and how they care about Shigure. There are some funny jokes and there are some things in here not for all ages, more like 16+. There is no adult content in this game unlike the main series, but there are implied nudes like steam covering certain body parts and Talk that's not for kids. It is a complete story-driven game and there are no choices, you are just here for the ride. You can, however, hit a button on the top right that lets you pet any of the Six Cat girls and Shigure. You also get achievements doing that. This is a good and cute game, but it's not worth the full price. Definitely get it on sale or in a bundle like I did. [b] Grade A

144049435.review:
100/10 Game of the year 2015-2023

Un Viaje Encantador al Mundo de las Nekomimis, adéntrate en el fascinante cosmos de "Nekopara", donde las entrañables nekomimis cobran existencia en una novela visual cautivante. Desde el vibrante diseño de los caracteres hasta los meticulosamente detallados escenarios, te sumergirás en un universo donde humanos y nekomimis coexisten en perfecta armonía en la afamada pastelería "La Soleil". A través de diálogos conmovedores y cotidianos instantes, te conectarás íntimamente con figuras emblemáticas como Chocola y Vanilla, experimentando de cerca sus emociones y aspiraciones más profundas. La música y los efectos sonoros envuelven cada escena, añadiendo una capa sensorial a la experiencia. Si estás en busca de una narrativa encantadora que despierte sonrisas y te inmiscuya en un mundo mágico, "Nekopara Vol 0" se presenta como una elección innegablemente cautivadora para incoar en esta innegablemente virtuosa franquicia.

135154688.review:
Tags: psychological horror

Before you buy, you must ask yourself, what do you want to achieve from buying this game? Is it a simple dopamine rush for seeing cute anime girls? Is it the feeling of being thought about why you are away by cute cat girls because no one does that in real life? Is it to simply pat them on the head? Or do you have intentions that meet the cat's eye?

Despite its cute story and the fluffy story that it offers on a surface level, it has made question reality and the very existence of life. How come something so fluffy, be so mundane, when it never happened in my life? The story may be wholesome for a normal person, but repeating the story over and over just to suck the life out of me for trading cards has been quite the experience. 

To think that a visual novel that's like 5 minutes of skip time and no choices, can ruin one's mind like this because of its repetitive nature. It has achieved what most denpa visual novels wished for. A denpa is simply a visual novel niche, that makes one question reality like me right now. 

It made me realize, how life can be a tedious loop of the same cycle, hearing all the things that you already know from the first time you have read it. The characters may look cute but some are downright insane, like your little sister. She smelled your sheets and she thought that it was the sweetest smell ever, even though it must be filled with drool. It reminded me of a carnal beast smelling the scent of its prey. And the worst part is, she isn't even a cat girl.

The other girls will ruin a pacifist worldview in a second, after fighting over petty fights, pettier than a short, bratty tsundere who thinks she's smart after writing an overanalyzed review of a simple game. You simply watch them confused, why are they fighting over something so minuscule?

Are they even real girls? Or are they just standees made with cardboard and jiggle physics? It's like making fun of me. "Hahaha, you're a real woman, loser, this is why you got no boyfriend." And it made me cry like a b**** in denial. I cried so hard, that I heard the sound of the cat girls laughing at me, as I watch them sleep peacefully after making fun of me. 

And they repeated it, over. And over. Over again. In Japanese and Chinese, even! They make put me to shame as they look at me like an illiterate swine. It hurt my pride. All those wholesome feelings I have felt from the start vanished into this feeling of emptiness as it repeated over and over. 

But I finally got my last card to sell it off. 

And that was the last thing I knew when I saw my father go out to get milk as he looked at me with a disappointed look on his face.

This game has given me hell, and more hell to come.

132286190.review:
[I]Nekopara[/I] is a cinematic masterpiece. The scene opens with a ray of sun shining into the protagonist's eyes. This leaves much room for the player, as they are left with much confusion. The player will be left with questions such as, 'How did we get here" or "What happened?" leaving an excellent opening to the game.
   This initial scene is a great opening to introduce, which [I]Nekopara[/I] does skillfully. Each and every character is introduced at a skillfully placed time, leaving gameplay to remain exciting and unexpected. "We're having bacon and eggs today." is a wonderful line that probably took ages to come up with. This line is heavily foreshadowing the monstrous event during [spoiler] breakfast, in which the player was unable to eat breakfast, due to the fact that two of the girls were fighting. This demonstrates wonderful character progression, as later on they are seen fighting the same challenges. [/spoiler] Another event that really struck a chord with me was the boss fight at 11 in the morning. It isn't much of a spoiler, but unfortunately, it is scripted. [spoiler] During this time, you, the main character , are out of the house for unforeseen circumstances. During this time, the heroines are left to fight the monstrous beast of the bathroom.[/spoiler] This boss is one of the worst bosses of the game, as it only gets better than this. Fighting the boss is sort of like playing [I]Dark Souls[/I], but instead of playing on a controller or keyboard, you are playing with a flight stick. The controls are unfavorable, and poorly thought out. 
   Meanwhile, the character development is impeccable. Unfortunately, this part of the review will get into sensitive topics, so if you are uncomfortable with that, please skip ahead. [spoiler] Unfortunately, both Maple and Azuki are killed around the second boss fight with the popcorn flavored air freshener, which is quite a shame as the character development was starting to hint at something wonderful. The other girls tried to save them, but were halted by the miniboss, “Shigure” and had to watch as their chance of saving them decreased. The next scene jump cuts to the girls in the stages of grief, as they have just lost two of the people that they were the closest to. You don’t really feel a sense of happiness from them until the next hour when the time for laundry arrives and it is revealed that they are alright. This is one of the main problems that the game has story wise, it lacks commitment and starts to get a little predictable by the end.[/spoiler]
   Now the bad, the game's controls are really simple, and really bad at times. All you really have to control the characters is one button with a couple extra moves, four of which being save buttons. The battles, especially the first boss battle, can feel really wonky, and even tedious at times due to the lack of variety in combos. This is not to say the game is bad, I just really hope they improve upon this in [I]Nekopara Volume 1[/I]. 
   There are many games that are rushed to release without much care for what they represent, this is not the case with [I]Nekopara Vol 0[/I] but you can clearly tell that the developers struggle with combat mechanics. Overall, I would say this game is around an 8/10 if you care only for the story. The boss battles aren’t too hard, and don’t really have much room to mess up, due to the limited moveset you are supplied with. 

Editors Note: The difficulty slider does nothing.

Nekopara Vol. 0 is a prequel to first game (and actually the second game to be released, right?) It shows the events right before Kashou decided to move out of his family's household, including some revelations about the true intention behind Shigure's plan...

It is easier to enjoy this title since it is just a silly kinetic novel with astonishing art. There is no R18 patch, if that's what you're looking for [spoiler]go to horny jail![/spoiler]. The engine is the same from Vol. 1 and everything works just as smoothly. As in the other games, you can select two languages (i.e. English & Japanese) for the subtitles which is quite handy if you're trying to practice some Kanji.

I do enjoy the humour and the silliness of the catgrils and taking the R18-thing out of the way was actually beneficial here imho.

Worked out-of-the-box on Linux with Proton (thanks Valve!). Achievements are working fine too and cards still have an okay-ish price.

122760853.review:
[h1] Catgirl Heaven [/h1]

NEKOPARA Vol. 0 is a prequel to the first true game in the NEKOPARA series of visual novels. These visual novels certainly aren't known for their stories and this game is no exception. you don't buy a NEKOPARA game for a deep, emotional, or meaningful story. You buy these games for the catgirls, and this game certainly provides the goods. Each of the many catgirls have their own distinct personality and features that make them unique so you'll quickly find yourself finding a favorite quite quickly (Team Vanilla). The art is very well done, with great models, and fluid animation. There are times when the game has more chibi style artwork for some scenes and these are very well done as well. The voice acting is nice as well. The game was a lot funnier than I expected to be honest. You spend a day with the catgirls and watch as they get themselves into wacky situations and just be themselves. This game is very sexual with its humor but it's also quite wholesome and charming and at the end you're treated to some lewd scenes. There are no choices to make in this game, all you can do is move on with the story on the one set path which is perfectly fine since it's just a prequel and quite short at that. If you're a fan of catgirls and want something you can turn your brain off to and play this is the series for you and this is a fine place to start with it. For more reviews, follow my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/40795588/] curator page. [/url]

111365781.review:
[b]December 5th, 2021[/b]

"I've decided I want a break from Volume 1 for now. I think I'll go through Volume 0 for the time being, and since its a prequel it's something I haven't seen yet."

Another approximation of something that I said to my friends, during my wade through the trenches that manifested as Nekopara: Volume 1. I had uncharacteristically taken a break from playing Nekopara: Volume 1 in the middle of my play-through. I was truly bored by the experience and could no longer tolerate reading, something which never happened before.

However, my quest to see the end of the series drove me to keep consuming. I was playing right into the grubby paws of NEKO WORKS and their desire to sell a product. Although, it appeared I had run out of mainline Nekopara games to consume, Volumes 2, 3, & 4 behind me, and Volume 1 leaving me in a stalemate. Well, they knew that all good things must come to an end, but their beginning can be further extended; also known as PREQUELS!

There was a new dimension of the Nekopara franchise for the developers to expand the lore, and players to uncover it and piece it with what they knew already. "Explore the lore", was the motto behind my motivation to continue, despite my impatience with Volume 1.

The first natural step in this side of the lore was Volume 0, a game that predates Volume 2, and introduces features that would stick, including petting, and achievements relating to something other than changing the language and clicking through the story rapidly. This made future games more challenging, from both a physical and mental standpoint, as you could no longer 100% them without a keyboard, and the presence of petting as a whole introduces a new layer of interactivity, which may be a good or bad thing, depending on your opinion. I only used the features to get all of the achievements, or as a comedic element in my streams over Discord.

There is very little substance to Volume 0, to the point where the review will be relatively brief compared to my others so far.

However, this does not make Volume 0 the worst in the series. Volume 0, unlike Volume 1 and a certain [i]other[/i] entry that I will discuss after this one, has a level of success in accomplishing its reason for existing. I wouldn't define Volume 0 as good, more that Volume 0 wasn't meant to do very much, and isn't as much of a failure as its predecessor because it set out to do less than Volume 1.

But, as per usual with these reviews, its time to discuss a different part of the overarching universe that has some minor connection to the game in question: and that is the catgirls, ya know, the reason people buy these games.

A reader of my previous reviews will likely ask themselves "wait, didn't he already discuss catgirls twice already"? Well this time is a little different. Instead of a view of the catgirls and their relationship with their world, we will examine the catgirls and their impact on readers, the sort of connection to a character that crosses a computer screen, and a resulting compulsion to continue reading.

Some readers of this virtual novel will have their attachment to the catgirls only reach that of a physical attraction, which is the main method the game uses to draw in consumers, and that is the connection that many will stay with. These are mainly the people who downloaded the game with the sole purpose of getting the most out of the "adult content" (these people know who they are).

Many readers will take a step beyond this, examining the surface level characteristics that the characters exude, identifying with or antagonizing the ones they see as 'cute' or 'funny' or 'oh my god this character is super fucking creepy and exploits catgirls to have sex with her brother'. I will admit I have fallen into that camp, and still have some of these attachments, positive or negative, with many of the characters in the games, some feelings stronger than others.

However, there also exists a connection that I have taken on that expands beyond characteristics, and extends to the characters in relation to their circumstances. The catgirls are, as I have discussed in previous reviews, trapped in a society where they are a sub-class of citizen (for more details I suggest you read my other Nekopara reviews because I don't want to explain this for a third time). Additionally, the catgirls of Nekopara find themselves living with Shigure, a puppet-master sorts over the entire cast. They are blissfully unaware, or accepting, of the situation they find themselves in, and because of this I find myself feeling a new emotion that may have been missed by many who experienced this series; [b]pity[/b].

I find myself pitying the catgirls collectively, rather than as individuals. It was a feeling that has stayed with me since I stopped laughing at Volume 2 and started thinking with a clear mind. These catgirls act freely, but ultimately, it's Shigure calling the shots as to whose best interests they are acting for, and that's how it always has been. This pity served as motivation to keep reading, to see what would happen next, to scream into the screen as a conscience for the characters, hoping they would hear and snap to their senses. My feelings were as pitiable as the characters behind the screen, as that's what they are, characters behind a screen. It was the product of someone else that I couldn't change. I could only watch it unfold as it was scripted, as though it were an exhibit at some forsaken museum. Pity was all I had, and closure was something I could only dream of. 

What does this have to do with Volume 0? Well, it is the least connected to the rest of the main series, choosing instead to examine a day in the lives of the Minaduki catgirls, and it was an escape from the pity cycle I found myself in. I could return to a different layer of connection to the catgirls, viewing their characteristics for what they were, and not their situation (aside from the moments featuring the life-ruining Shigure). The most defining feature that contributes to this is the fact that we are not viewing this story as Kashou, as we have become accustomed to so far, instead we are outsiders looking in. We are not seeing the catgirls's reactions to Kashou, rather their actions alone. It was a breath of fresh air, and quite literally just a breath. Volume 0 takes less than an hour to read, and I only have more time than that because I went back to get the achievements. It's fine, for what it is; a collection of bite-sized stories following the not-so-mundane typical activities of the catgirls. It was a cute little distraction, and I say it played that role quite well.

If you like the Nekopara series for what it is, you can't go wrong with Volume 0. If you like Nekopara for the ironic enjoyment like I do, then keep in mind that this one's short, and isn't really worth it unless it's on sale, or if no cost is too great for you. I left Volume 0 ready for the next installment on my agenda, but little did I realize what was in store for me.

tl;dr: nya nya catgirl game's day off is a bite sized escape from the norm. 5/10

I can not describe how absolutely infuriating this game was. This is literally the most misogynistic game I have ever seen! There cat girls are the epitome of the male-gaze, with a way to make their breasts more "bouncy" and the voice acting was so annoying. It sounds like they got a couple of 10 year olds to record it. 
Now you might be thinking is there at least an interesting plot? Is the game kinda fun at some parts? I would love to say yes, but alas not in the slightest. Would you like a sneak peak into what this game considers a plot? Catgirls sniffing pillows! Catgirls making a mess while cooking! Catgirls...existing. I have never wanted to punch my computer until the moment I played this game but the lack of plot, direct and unfiltered misogyny and annoying voice acting made me literally want to vomit. I hated everything to do with this game and would obviously not recommend this to anyone.

Surprisingly good, and somehow leaves a much less bitter taste when you finish it than with Vol 1. 

I really don't know how, but this one was far more engaging despite the lack of a protagonist, or any interesting plot points/goals. All the game had to offer in order to make it worth the money was just showing the player what an ordinary day in the Minaduki Household is like.

95132964.review:
This is a prequel to Nekopara Vol. 1. I recommend starting with the first volume before moving on to this one, as it keeps things a bit more interesting and less confusing to follow.

It is a short and quickly paced visual novel with a simple, comedic plot. Just a day in a life of cat girls under their master Shigure - a younger sister of a dude named Kashou who aspires to open his own bakery. Kashou is elsewhere for the entirety of the visual novel, so the focus is naturally on the cute and juvenile interactions between the cat girls and Shigure. It has more blatant sexual references [spoiler](Cinnamon really carries this game...)[/spoiler] than the first volume, but it's mainly done in the comedic tone as opposed to romantic.

Besides the petting mechanic (the button that appears at the top right of the screen as you read through the visual novel; literally just pet the sprites and they respond with cute noises and animations), this volume isn't anything special. It is still pretty high quality with its overall presentation, particularly with the art, the user interface, sprite manipulation and voice acting. Makes for a good distraction while also pretty cheap. 

I can recommend volume zero if you are into that sort of thing, but I still suggest dipping your toes with volume one first if you are new to the Nekopara series.

Por ejemplo, la relación que guarda el texto Cosecha roja de Dashiell Hammett con el archigénero épico o narrativo, el subgénero narrativo novela y la clase de textos novela policiaca.

94396882.review:
This game, though only an introduction to the franchise is a masterpiece.

I was minding my own business when my friend sent through a gift. The contents? Nekopara Vol. 0, and a message saying that I should be grateful. At first, I was confused, what is Nekopara? I found myself asking. As I viewed the store page, I saw and believed that it was simply a dating simulator for catgirls... Boy was I wrong.

Calling it simply a Catgirl Dating Sim is almost an insult to the wonderful franchise that is Nekopara. As I launched the game with low expectations, I was blasted in the face with an awesome loading screen and a magnificent soundtrack. Just the beautiful starting visuals had made me click the [Game Start] button in anticipation. As the screen faded from black the story commences, and by the Gods, was it an amazing experience.

Before launching the game, I had changed the character voices to be dubbed in Japanese. This was one of the choices made that made me truly come to appreciate Nekopara. If I could describe the voice acting of the characters in one word, it would be IMMACULATE. The contrast between the different characters was amazing, from quiet to bubbly, the game had such a diverse range. The personality of the characters were all different and unique in their own ways making this game one of a kind.

The design of the characters were awesome and like the personality, were unique. The Nekopara cast had voluptuous and lithe bodies that really was one of the key driving forces of this game. Another key feature of Nekopara games are the ability to pet the character's heads, this just improved this to a whole other level. The action was cute and made me feel bubbly inside causing me to really appreciate this game.

Overall, this game is awesome and definitely worth it, playing it made me happy, made me smile.

My final verdict on this game is 12/10 (because 11 isn't enough).
Assured to be going down into the history books of greatest games and definitely recommended to be bought.

93133969.review:
This release of the Nekopara series leans more towards wholesomeness but not as much as Nekopara Extra. The scenes present contain more nudity than what is commonly displayed in other media, but the nudity present is somewhat infrequent. Sexual themes are more present in this instance of Nekopara.

Nekopara 0 is a more relaxed game with the daily lives of the iconic catgirls. I'm not a devout fan of slice-of-life stories, so bear with me as I review the game. The plot occurs within one day and passes by chronologically from when the characters wake up to when they sleep for the night. The game implements pretty alright sources of humor, an iconic staple of the series. The story was alright and had some more design character traits but they aren't as well written as I would have appreciated for my average to high standards. In addition, I did think the catgirls eating actual cat food was a little disgusting to stomach. The gameplay is too linear, a fatal flaw present for all releases so far. The game would have benefited from minor choices or enhanced interaction with the Minaduki catgirls beyond rubbing their head, breasts, or stomach.

To summarize, I would call this a more teen friendly experience and I recommend this to Nekopara followers who need more to fuel their catgirl addiction. 7/10 Average.

91472609.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

91389377.review:
Nekopara Vol. 0 is an allegorical modern western that captures a country in transition, thus commenting on present day society and providing an almost nostalgic analysis of the nature of good and evil and the inescapable stranglehold of fate.
Sticking to most genre rules, only to pull out the rug from underneath you at the very end, Nekopara Vol. 0 together with Call of Duty: Black Ops seem to best represent what the modern Western can be. They are almost polar opposites in how they approach what they try to say, but they're still sides of the same coin.
On a literal level the plot is very straightforward, carried by a host of intriguing characters and can be seen as a classic cat and booba game. That's the beauty of this game, that even on a superficial level it is better than most games. It is entertaining, never loosens its grip, is extremely violent and drenched in a brilliant and often subtle irony, something the Nekoworks do like no other.
Another thing that I absolutely love about this game is its tranquil atmosphere. Sure, there is a lot of action and violence in it, but there is always this permanent sense of calm. The best way to explain this is by taking a look at the opening scenes. Quietly shot, that first murder has, for all its horror, a kind of stillness over it. Switch to Azuki hunting and I'm glued to the screen, readily accepting going under this game's mesmerizing powers, strengthened by the bizarre absence of not music.
It is shot beautifully. The attention to detail is admirable, the crispness and gorgeously lit images are simply stunning. It seems as if everyone involved in translating the novel to game brought their best and managed to create this visual treat. Even when nothing is going on you cannot help but admire and marvel at the visuals on display.
Digging a little deeper there is a lot to mull over underneath the surface. I haven't watched the anime, but think Nekoworks is an interesting voice in American literature. I don't think I ever will watch the anime as I get the distinct impression that Nekoworks managed to capture its themes really well. It at points feels like a novel unfolding before your eyes.
The eight central characters seem to be the embodiment of everything this film has to say. Nekopara Vol. 0, obviously, refers to the fact that society is changing and that values change along with it. Representing the old values, we are presented with Kashou. You can read the road map of his past from the lines of his face. He is nostalgia personified, unable to understand the change that is happening to his surroundings despite all the wisdom he has gathered in his life. He knows a lot but understands nothing resulting in the only logical outcome, he turns his back on everything accepting his fate and becoming stagnant. Physically he doesn't die at the end, but spiritually he does.
Juxtaposed to the Kashou we are given the personification of change. An unstoppable force of nature that has no conscience. But the beauty of Chocola and the way the brilliant VA portrays her is that she is not a simple angel of death. Not simply evil, she also embodies fate, showing us the random nature of life and the inescapable qualities of fate. Chocola is not so much what society will become, but more the change that is needed to get to where it's going.
(There are slight spoilers in this paragraph)
Veering between these two is this film's everywoman, Cinnamon. She is the vessel through which we experience the story. Neither good nor bad, she is at the whim of the universe as she never seems to have control over what is going on. Nekoworks seem to use her ironically to show us how helpless we are in the bigger scheme of things. For example, Cinnamon is weird and horny which is, according to standard values, wrong. But she almost gets away with it. It ironically goes wrong when she tries to perform an act of kindness. This sets in motion the series of events that eventually lead to her death. Try as she might, she has no control over it.
In the end, with themes as big as this running through it, what resonates most with me is the tonal change of the final act, initiated by the way Nekoworks handles Cinnamon's death. It happens off screen, completely negating the importance of the plot and storytelling conventions only to shift to a more spiritual tone. It is here that Kashou comes to his epiphany that he has to accept that his place in life is not what he originally intended it to be. He seems to accept that he has done enough and can leave the protection of his world to others. He grasps the concept that understanding the world is far less important than understanding yourself. This also leads to the much debated ending that doesn't sit well with many people. I think many people dislike it because of its abruptness but also because they were not given the traditional climactic confrontation between protagonist and antagonist. I, for one, love it as it perfectly exemplifies the fleeting nature of life and in it Kashou speaks the definitive words that encompass what this whole journey has been about for him.
'And then I woke up.'

I have to admit, I had my doubts when I first learned of the story. After all, Nekopara? Will this story even be good? How ignorant was I to even have these thoughts. Little did I know I was about to indulge in what may have been the best 1 hours and 51 minutes of my life. The story started out strong. The opening scenes enticed the audience with a captivating enigma. I was so taken aback from the next-generation animation that I almost didn't even realize the underlying symbolism in the ongoing scenes. It wasn't until my twenty sixth viewing of the story where I finally got my bearings together and was able to focus on the gripping and labyrinthine stratagem. The underlying analogy for 19th century dystopianism and the evangelical deviation of typical orthodoxy was enlightening to say the least. Just when I thought the story could not get any better, the increasing conflict before the climax began. I could not believe the complexity of the story as the main protagonist struggled with the everyday endeavors for a quintessential cat such as the consistent up- hill altercation of the fight against misogyny and the fiscal synergy of opposing interplanetary dynamisms. There I was, gripping to my chair as the conflict of the story began. I was so enticed by the story that I felt as if I was both practically and relatively a part of the story. This is a special kind of high that not even the strongest of drugs can give you. Was I part of the story? Am I inside the story right now? This story will leave you questioning existential nihilism and the objective skepticism of our perceived valuation of anthropological existence. At this point in the film, I was fully intoxicated by the avant-garde animated art style. That's when the plot finally aggrandized and I was completely stupefied. You could have lived a thousand years of isolation trying to predict the plot twist and you would never even scratch the surface of what actually transpires in the story. I was so bewildered that I actually had to pause the story so that my existential crisis didn't dive too deep inside of myself. Even pausing the story was surreal. It's almost as if life paused with the story. I felt as though I had actually become a cinematic tangent quantum. The effects are still wearing off and I haven't been able to watch the story in several years. I spent the following seven years afraid of what outside of my house actually looks like. Every single day and night I live in misery because I became fully aware that happiness is never achievable. I realized that human life has absolutely no meaning and that no matter what I ever do, it is of complete unimportance and in years from now, no recollection of my existence will prevail, meaning that if I died years ago, died now, or die sometime in the future it will not matter whatsoever to anyone. But, then again, the fact that I'm living doesn't matter either so I might as well stick around for awhile, living in complete isolation, condemned to a life of traumatic memories and a completely corrupted sub-conscience. Nekopara literally ruined my life. 10/10

85315083.review:
Nekopara Volume 0 is a lovely little instalment for the series. It takes place just before Volume 1, and only lasts about an hour and a half or so. If you're playing through the entire series, be aware that it's not mandatory for you to play this game, it mostly just exists for additional catgirl content for those who enjoy these games.

The main content of the game is spectating the catgirls in their daily lives at the family home, you are not a protagonist or directly involved, you're just watching. This game introduced the petting feature which allows you to either pet the characters on the head to provoke a positive response (which is what you should be doing) or...touch other places if you're perverse and / or scandalous.

Since this is a short game, I'll honour it with a shorter review. The music, visuals, voice acting and story is very pleasant. NekoWorks puts a lot of effort into their craft and it shows. They've created some adorable characters and a story, that may seem quite silly at face value, but also, that captured the hearts of many including myself.

You really don't have anything to lose other than an hour and a half, so if you're even a little bit intrigued, please, give it a shot! Obviously, the theme and the anime-esque tropes may not be for everyone, but you may end up being pleasantly surprised!

81887763.review:
Every so often, a visual novel fan just wants to unwind with a brief, cutesy little experience. At least, that’s the case for some of us after reading through any of the 40+ hour time commitments that some of the genre’s best require. Nekopara Vol. 1 fell into the category of silly fluff when it launched late last year. The game revolved around the story of a young man by the name of Kashou Minaduki who was finally pursuing his dream of opening up a bakery. Unbeknownst to him, his two family pets — cat girls to be exact — mailed themselves over to the location and took it upon themselves to become his bakery’s first staff members. Although the story was definitely not a sprawling, serious tale it provided a good deal of amusement and fanservice for those who enjoy both.

Instead of Vol. 2, which is still upcoming from developer Neko Works, a prequel made its way onto Steam. Titled Nekopara Vol. 0, it’s a “fandisc,” meaning its meant for fans of Nekopara Vol. 1 to get even more of the precocious Chocola, Vanilla and all the other Minaduki household humanoid kitties. Those who are brand new to the world of this visual novel should honestly gravitate toward the original title first and then appraise whether or not they are interested in even more of the experience. As a fandisc, it also proves a far shorter playtime and one that doesn’t provide deep insight into the events of the main game. Honestly, it doesn’t provide much of anything at all unless you’re desperately in love with the cast.

The reason I say this is because you get little with Nekopara Vol. 0. This story takes place when Kashou still lived at home and therefore coexisted with his harem of cat girls. Unlike Vol. 1, however, Kashou doesn’t even really exist. He appears at one point and is often the topic of discussion, but never exerts himself as a protagonist or even utter a word. Instead, this time around players are simply a passive audience to all the shenanigans that the cat group can get into. Well, the cats and Kashou’s younger sister. She might as well be part of the harem though as her brother complex is played up once again for amusement.
 
If all you’re looking to do for 45 minutes is watch cutesy cat girls goof off and sometimes say lewd things, then you’re in for a great time. However, if you’re looking to learn much of anything more about the cast or Kashou’s past you’ll be sorely disappointed. Then again, it’s worth recalling that the original visual novel was fairly simple too. It’s just unfortunate to see how vapid this release turned out. As with before, this is still a visual novel that offers the player no choices at any point. There is one ending and everyone receives it if they read through to completion. You’ll find achievements to collect, though they are related mostly to petting each character. The “pet” mechanic is brand new but just amps up the cute factor and doesn’t actually impact the progression.

Luckily, one excellent aspect from Nekopara Vol. 1 still remains: the lovely artwork! Sure, it’s anime artwork like so many other visual novels out there but each character is strikingly adorable. Not only that, but the colors of their clothes and eyes absolutely pop. The “E-mote” animation system is still at work and turns what would often be static character art in a visual novel and brings it to semi-life. Each character blinks, speaks, breathes, and generally adds a good dynamic touch to scenes. CG art also showcases just how wonderfully goofy the group can be. The game is fully voiced in Japanese and players may choose to read through in English, Chinese, or Japanese.

Finally, there’s the matter of the writing. This is a visual novel, after all! For the most part it feels akin to any average anime. Character dialogue is readable and makes sense, but isn’t particularly realistic (not as if the tale of a bunch of cat girls is meant to be relatable). Most of the time it just feels that the characters are constantly busy one-upping each other, and while that comes through, it isn’t particularly interesting to read. That point will vary depending on who is playing, but it’s how things felt during my playthrough. Who would expect that when you get a bunch of cat girls together and let them go crazy the result is utter boredom?

80222298.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 38.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

I'm not really sure what I've just played... if you can even call it that?
It's a visual novel, doesn't have any gameplay, so don't expect that (being able to pet their cute little heads doesn't count).
This is the very first of a series, so you'll have to buy the other games to continue the story.
It's a silly little story with some really cute and pretty characters, not to mention the art is really good! But what else did I expect from Sayori? Her art has always been awesome.

Do I recommend it? Sure. Kind of. I suppose I had an alright time, even though some things do drag on for a bit too long sometimes and it can get extremely tedious... I didn't have that much fun, in fact, I was bored most of the time.

For me specifically, it was worth getting to decorate my profile with adorably cute badges, emotes and profile backgrounds, otherwise, if you're not into that, don't really bother.

74373921.review:
Ingredientes para un pastel de papa
1 diente de ajo
2 cebollas
1 morrón rojo
2 tomates
1/4 de taza de vino tinto
1 zanahoria
600 gramos de carne picada magra
300 cc de caldo de verduras
1 cucharada de ají molido
1 cucharada de pimentón
1 pizca de sal
1 pizca de pimienta negra
2 hojitas de laurel
1 cucharada de orégano
2 cucharadas de aceite de oliva
6 papas
1 taza de leche
2 cucharadas de manteca
Preparación
Paso 1

En una sartén grande, poner el aceite de oliva y el ajo picado. Cuando el ajo empiece a dorarse, agregar la cebolla y el morrón, ambos cortados en cubos.

Paso 2

Dejar que se cocine unos minutos y, en cuanto los vegetales comiencen a pegarse a la sartén, desglasar con vino tinto (añadir el vino y raspar la sartén para levantar el fondo de cocción).

Paso 3

Dejar evaporar el alcohol 2 o 3 minutos y agregar el tomate sin piel y sin semillas, cortado en cubos, la zanahoria en rodajas bien finas y la carne picada.

Paso 4

Mezclar bien, desarmando los bloques de carne con una cuchara de madera y cocinar unos minutos. Condimentar con un poco de sal, pimienta, pimentón, ají molido, orégano y laurel.

Paso 5

Agregar caldo hasta cubrir y cocinar hasta reducir el líquido, revolviendo para que no se pegue. Añadir más caldo o agua si fuera necesario, para cocinarlo largo rato.

Paso 6

Mientras tanto, hervir las papas peladas y cortadas en cubos, hasta que estén bien tiernas. Hacer un puré y agregarle la manteca y la leche. Condimentar a gusto.

Paso 7

Llevar la carne picada súper jugosa a una fuente para horno y cubrir con el puré. Gratinar en horno fuerte y servir.​

73082571.review:
I am a 42 y/o father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 16. Samuel got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with him, for he is always out with his friends or just watching people play on YouTube.

I had him create a Steam account for me, and purchased this title to see if I could perhaps play alongside him. I loaded into the game, chose my nation, and started playing, except I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked Samuel for help, and he hosted a multiplayer match so that I could join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since his mother passed away due to C-19. Hearts of Iron IV has since then, brought me and my adolescent son closer again, to the point he's found the enthusiasm to join me for fishing trips to our local lake. This purchase, albeit perhaps insignificant to some, has reminded me how there is fun to be had in video games despite my age. I just wish I had more time to play with him at home, though for now I'll settle for hotseat matches on his account; sometimes we argue about which focus tree to take next!
